content:
re :Just talking to spectrum gets failed logon error which configuration, email name or password are wrong.

Please check you have the following set up: Firewall Access Firewall which might be the one installed by default or controlled by an antipvirus product. Thunderbird must be set up as allowed program so that all ports etc are allowed.

Please confirm you have got Thunderbird set up an allowed program.

VPN if you have a VPN enabled please switch it off as most servers do not like VPN as it hides your IP and server thinks you are a hacker so blocks access.

Spectrum is a server used for various email addresses, so it would be useful to know what comes after the @ in your email address as that effects the server settings you need to use.

The following information is for setting up an IMAP account. So please tell me if you are tring to set up a Pop account.

Email addresses ending in 'Bresnan.net. charter.net and spectrum.net

  • Incoming Email Server: mobile.charter.net
  • Port 993
  • Connection SEcurity: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • Username : full email address

SMTP

  • Outgoing Email Server: mobile.charter.net
  • Port 587
  • Connection SEcurity: STARTTLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • Username : full email address

Email addresses ending in Brighthouse.com, bak.rr.com, bham.rr.com, cfl.rr.com, emore.rr.com, eufala.rr.com, indy.rr.com, mi.rr.com, panhandle.rr.com, tampabay.rr.com IMAP

  • Incoming Email Server: mail.brighthouse.com
  • Port 993
  • Connection SEcurity: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • Username : full email address

SMTP

  • Outgoing Email Server: mail.brighthouse.com
  • Port 587
  • Connection SEcurity: STARTTLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • Username : full email address

Email addresses ending in TWC.com and any domain ending in .rr.com not covered above IMAP

  • Incoming Email Server: mail.twc.com
  • Port 993
  • Connection SEcurity: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • Username : full email address

SMTP

  • Outgoing Email Server: mail.twc.com
  • Port 587
  • Connection SEcurity: STARTTLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • Username : full email address

In all cases the Password you enter is the same password you would enter when logging on to the spectrum etc webmail account via a browser.

To check your stored password is correct:

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Scroll to Passwords section
  • Click on 'Saved Passwords'
  • click on 'Show Passwords'

If asked for a 'Windows Security' password - when you start up computer and it asks for logon password - that is the password you need to enter. Are passwords correct? If no - right click on all relevant lines and select 'Edit Password' Completely remove all content and then carefully type the correct password If username is not correct - do check for typos - then use same process to 'Edit username' When finished - Click on 'Close'

Then restart Thunderbird to ensure all new settings are used correctly.

Did you set up a Pop or Imap mail account - the above info is for IMAP ?


If you get a login error - you need to upload an image of it into this forum question.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Ok, I m not the guru of compacting, but I will share my knowledge/experience and you've been waiting awhile. Compacting removes deleted messages from the folder, and it also rebuilds the index. A possible cause of confusion:: When a search is done. the global search uses the index, and users may rely on an older search after a message has been deleted. That is,, a search may indicate a message is present when it is not. There are millions of Thunderbird users; if messages were being deleted, even for 1% of users, there would be a massive outcry.

Regardless of our confidence in Thunderbird, as a business, I recommend daily backups because you are more likely to encounter a computer failure or a software crash or a virus infection. Having written that, many backups don't work, as evidenced from what we see here on the forum. The simplest backup that always works is this:

  1. If IMAP, do File>offline>download (to ensure all messages are on PC)
  2. ensure thunderbird is not running <== IMPORTANT
  3. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  4. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  5. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media

Those are the basic mechanics, but a detailed assessment of potentially lost messages since last backup is encouraged. For your question no how to restore 'lost' messages, I do not feel that is possible, as the messages may likely have previously been deleted. Othes may see possibilities.
creator: davidsk

content:
1. Please always state your version.

2. You wrote "Your information indicates that compacting would not cause any data loss." - where are you seeing this documented?

3. It is true that compact should not cause dataloss. And compact was rewritten in the past year, and tuned, to make this much better. But it can happen. It would be helpful to know what happened on your computer in the day(s) leading up to this failure - power loss? virus? rebooted without shutting down Thunderbird? anything else unusual? (more info at https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/compacting-folders-potential-complications )

4. As for recovering from your present situation, in addition to what david has stated, "compacting would not cause any data loss ... has not been the case." is unfortunately vague. Please elaborate on exactly, precisely what you are seeing (or not seeing).

More background at https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/compacting-folders
creator: wsmwk

content:
Sounds like you may have tried to set up a Pop mail account as a deferred account more commonly called 'Global Inbox'. If you had set the Pop account up as a 'Global Inbox (Local Folders') and done it correctly then you would not see any pop mail account in the Folder Pane as it would be entirely using the 'Local Folders' mail account.

A new Pop account tends to create the 'Sent' etc folders when you actually send emails or save as draft etc.

For the following information I'm assuming you have created a Pop account, so please tell me if you have set an Imap account as that alters everything.

Please check you have the following set up for a normal Pop account.

  • In 'Account Settings'
  • Select 'Server Settings' for the account

Top right - Server Type: is it a Pop or Imap MAil Server?

Assuming POP

  • click on 'Advanced' button
  • You should have this selected: 'Inbox for this account'
  • click on 'OK'

In left pane:

  • Select 'Copies & Folders'
  • Select 'Place a copy in'
  • Select: 'Sent folder on' and choose the pop mail account email address

Then check all the others. Message Archives

  • Select 'Keep messages in'
  • Select 'Archives folder on' and choose the same pop mail account

Drafts and Templates Keep draft messages in:

  • Select 'Drafts folder on' and choose the same pop mail account

Keep messages templates in:

  • Select 'Templates folder on' and choose the same pop mail account

In left pane

  • Select 'Junk Settings'
  • Select 'Enable adaptive junk mail comtrols for this account'
  • Select your address books so any contacts will be put as a whitelist of good email addresses.

Under 'Destination and Retention'

  • Select 'Move new junk messages to
  • Select 'Junk folder on' and choose the same pop mail account

Then exit Thunderbird, wait a few moments for background processes to complete then restart Thunderbird.

These are the basic settings for POP accounts. Please confirm you have checked them and tell us anything you had to set up.


General info: The 'Local Folders' account is a basic account created by default which can be an alternative storage for emails. It's particulary helpful for anyone who uses an Imap account as it means important emails can be copied to a folder in this account and they will be stored independently from server on your computer.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Hallo Bert,

Het lijkt er inderdaad op dat de automatische detectie heeft vastgesteld dat de 64-bitsversie kon worden geïnstalleerd. Op zich kan dat geen kwaad, standaard wordt namelijk de installatiemap van ESR gebruikt om de profielen correct om te kunnen zetten.

Waarschijnlijk kan de gehele map met de oude installatie verwijderd worden, maar om het zeker te weten kunt u het volgende proberen:

  1. Ga naar de bovenliggende map van de oude installatiemap (C:\Program Files)
  2. Geen de oude Thunderbird-installatiemap een andere naam (b.v. ‘Mozilla Thunderbird_OUD’)
  3. Start Thunderbird

Als Thunderbird normaal start en werkt, worden er geen bestanden uit de oude installatie gebruikt en kan de nu hernoemde map gerust worden verwijderd. Werkt Thunderbird niet goed, hernoem deze map dan weer naar de oude naam. Het is daarna wel zaak om uit te zoeken welke bestanden in die map nog gebruikt worden en deze op de juiste manier over te zetten.
creator: markh2

content: Please clarify. Are you stating that messages sent from two other PCs and an Iphone do not appear in your sent folder? That could happen if one or more of the devices store sent messages locally. If the other devices all show sent messages done by the others, but none show sent messages from your PC, then your PC is storing messages locally or not at all. Check the copies&folders section of the account. I also suggest sending a test message from one of the other devices and verify which devices see the sent message.

content:
Bearded said
Hello, gentlements! I have installed Thunderbird via POP3 protocol. I can receive mail, but not send. Yesterday I bought BitDefender Premium Security with VPN (Unlimited traffic). As soon as I turned it on, I can't send any more messages. When I turn it off, I can send messages normally. My VPN is set to my country (Croatia). Can someone help me how to get Thunderbird to work as before? I would like to point out that I really need a VPN, because I work with sensitive data. Here are the settings for the incoming and outgoing servers:

Yeah, looks like BitDefender VPN is blocking the SMTP port (25/587). Try changing the outgoing port to 465 with SSL/TLS, or whitelist Thunderbird in BitDefender’s firewall/VPN settings. You can also try switching the VPN server, some block mail ports to prevent spam.

To select the folders to search, click the Choose button. A dialog will be displayed that contains a hierarchical view of all the folders in all of your accounts. Select the check box next to each folder you wish to include in the search.

Choose one of three search modes: Match all messages: This means you have no search criteria and are just using the saved search to combine the contents of multiple folders and display them as a single folder.

content:
The change is that you now have a choice of continuing with the ExtendedSupportRelease (ESR) version or switching to the new Monthly version that will have the latest releases and updated monthly. These two URLs provide more info: - https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/choosing-thunderbird-release-channel - https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-release

You now have a choice, but switching is an option, as the ESR will continue to be supported. If you wish to remain with ESR, no action is needed. Thanks for asking.

content: I regret that my knowledge deficiency on this topic prevents my giving a full explanation. In summary, this indicates an error in the email provider's server setup for the domain. Email servers check back to the source of an email account's server to see if the domain name appearing from that domain is actually hosted there. This is a common technique of scammers, people who pretend that the domain in their email account is legitimate.

content:
In your mail account, any emails that get 'forwarded' by the filter, should have a right curved arrow next to them positioned to the left of the Subject. If you also enable 'threads', you can see what was actually forwarded and to whom. Anything that did not get forwarded may not have those set against the email.

This might help to locate the email and then you can check with Message Filter to see what email address it should have been forwarded to.

In 'Message Filters', did you create a filter to auto 'Forward' mail ? If yes, you could check the 'Filter Log'

First make sure it's been enabled. In 'Message Filters' for the account that forwards the emails. Click on 'Filter Log' button Top left - is the checkbox 'Enable the Filter Log' selected ? If no then select it now. Click on 'Close'

That filter log will display, date and time, name of filter applied and also a lot more info about which mail got filtered. It should be reasonably easy to search for the relevant filter name. Data is just text, so can be copy pasted to another program to facilate any type of search.

You can also clear the log every so often, so it does not get enormous.

Where is the data actually stored: In the profile folder the file that keeps a log is the mail account name folder and is called 'filterlog.html' which you can open using eg: Notepad++ or OpenOffice Writer or even in a browser.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:

It would be so much simpler if the error message would include the email account name from which the error occurred.

Thanks again.

content: email service provider?? Would that be Spectrum?
creator: Sunvee

content:
It may be. Spectrum is an internet service provider (ISP) that, like most ISPs, has also provided e-mail service. Some Spectrum customers use Spectrum's e-mail services. Many Spectrum customers get their internet access from Spectrum but use e-mail services from Google, Apple, Microsoft, Yahoo, et al.

The part of your e-mail address after "@", which is the domain, indicates the e-mail service provider (unless the user has their own domain). Spectrum has bought other internet service providers and taken over their domains, e.g., Time Warner and Brighthouse, so it's not always obvious that Spectrum is the service provider.

Probably doesn't matter: Spectrum is no longer providing e-mail accounts for new internet customers, but still provides them for existing customers.

content:
I expect you would recommend I find where the old App of Thunderbird resides; uninstall the new version I just downloaded and re-install the new version it in the same location as my old 128esr version.

No, it actually doesn't matter where the 128esr version is installed. And there is no point re-installing the new version.

Start the new version, check which profiles exist, and which one is actually being used by the new version. At the top right of the Thunderbird window, click the menu button ≡, then select Help > Troubleshooting Information. Under the Application Basics section, find the 'Profiles' row, then click on about:profiles.

Please post a screenshot showing the existing profiles on the about:profiles page. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/how-do-i-create-screenshot-my-problem

content:
So you're now running TB139 with the profile 'Default User', but it has none of your data, correct?

Try the other two existing profiles 'default-release' and 'default' by clicking the corresponding 'Launch profile' button. If one of those profiles shows all your data, set it as the default profile, by clicking the 'Set as default profile' button.

When Thunderbird 139 starts with the correct profile again, you can uninstall the TB128 application.

"default" 99.9% of the time will be empty, so that is expected. It is just a useless dummy profile.

content:
Close any instance of Thunderbird currently running.

Copy the contents of the default-esr profile, i.e. all files and folders underneath the path C:\Users\lsvan\AppData\Local\Packages\MozillaThunderbird.MZLA_h5892qc0xkpca\LocalCashe\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\24tjytvo.default-esr to the path C:\Users\lsvan\AppData\Roaming\thunderbird\profiles\h9pf3zqk.default. The latter is the profile TB139.0 is using by default. Replace any files or folders which may already exist there.

Start TB139. Does your data show up now? If so, uninstall TB128.
